content.definition: Pathology affecting the brachial artery, including iatrogenic injury from cardiac catheterization, traumatic injury (supracondylar fracture, penetrating trauma), and thrombosis. The brachial artery is the main arterial supply to the arm, continuing from axillary to bifurcate into radial and ulnar arteries at the antecubital fossa.

anatomy.relations: Medial to biceps tendon, median nerve crosses anterior
anatomy.branches: Deep brachial (profunda brachii), superior/inferior ulnar collateral

management: Emergent exploration for supracondylar fracture with absent pulse

clinical_pearls: Supracondylar fracture + pulseless = surgical emergency (brachial artery trapped)
Volkmann contracture: flexor compartment ischemia from missed brachial injury
Brachial artery spasm common in children - observe before exploration
Pink, pulseless hand may have adequate collateral flow - still warrants close monitoring
Avoid brachial artery for catheterization in patients needing future dialysis access

learning_objectives: Recognize supracondylar fracture with vascular injury
